Batchim is one of the most complicated parts of the Korean reading and writing system. However, we can still discuss the most basic parts of Batchim to kickstart your Korean learning journey!


Batchim is commonly found at the bottom or final consonant of a syllable block. When it comes to Batchim, there are some Korean letters that may change their sound depending if Bathchim applies to them or not.


To make things easier to understand here's an example situation: 

Let's use the word Batchim (받침) for example. If Batchim is not applied, the word "받침" itself should be read as "Bad-Chim". However, when rules of Batchim is applied, it should be "Batchim" wherein the letter ㄷ's sound in the syllable 받 is replaced with T instead of the usual D sound.


However, this does not only apply to the letter ㄷ. There are more Korean letters sounds that can change when Batchim is applied.


Here are some examples:

If you look at the figure above, we can see the Korean letters on the left side and their Latin or Roman letter counterpart on the right side when Batchim is applied.


One example is the letter ㅅ. Normally, the Korean letter ㅅ's sound should be similar to the letter S. However in Batchim, its sound completely changes and turns into the T sound.


Now, you might be wondering: When do you apply batchim? Well, in the next lesson, we're going to discuss when are you supposed to apply Batchim when reading and writing Korean words.

When a syllable block ends with a consonant, for example \"받\" and the next syllable block has a starting consonant, for example \"받침\" the 1st syllable block\'s ending consonant needs to apply the Batchim rule. Therefore, the last consonant on the 1st syllable block (Letter ㄷ) should sound similar to the letter T instead of the usual D sound.

However, this does not apply if the next syllable block\'s starting consonant is the letter ㅇ or the letter ㅎ. In that case, the final consonant on the 1st syllable block should retain its original sound.
